BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. On steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry slab avalanches are possible. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs will form. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding avalanches are the main danger. Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A moderate (level 2) danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.

As a consequence of snowfall and the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. The avalanche danger will persist. Fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.

In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1000 m. As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. As a consequence of rising temperatures and rain a crust formed on the surface. This applies in all aspects below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep sunny slopes.
Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet all the way through and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists.
Fresh wind slabs require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some snow fell on Sunday in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland.
The wind was strong at times in all regions.
The sometimes deep wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes. They are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack.
The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In the neighbouring regions and at intermediate and high altitudes the likelihood of avalanches is higher.
In the morning and where less new snow falls, the danger of falling on hard snow remains, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steeper sections.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunday: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from the afternoon above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Above approximately 2300 m a lot of snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
The old snowpack is hard and its surface has a crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Tuesday: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. On steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and medium-sized dry slab avalanches are possible. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Mostly small dry loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs will form. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Unexpected weather pattern: In localities where more snow falls the avalanche danger is greater. The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. On steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and medium-sized dry slab avalanches are possible. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Small and medium-sized dry loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. In localities where more snow falls the avalanche danger is greater.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs will form. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow will be deposited on the quite favourable surface of an old snowpack. From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the day progresses, a few moist snow slides are possible. The new snow is lying on the favourable surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs can only be released by large loads in most cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind, mostly small wind slabs will form. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some snow has fallen since yesterday.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs formed on New Year's Eve especially in the regions exposed to precipitation.
These can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The older wind slabs will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Some new snow to low altitudes. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Faceted weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Strong northwesterly wind: The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from southwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The somewhat older wind slabs will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in all aspects. Avalanche prone locations are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Avalanches can reach medium size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Over a wide area up to 15 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1500 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of snowfall and the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. The avalanche danger will persist. Fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.

A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies in the regions with a lot of snow on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.

In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1000 m. As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet all the way through and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases, this also applies on steep sunny slopes at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists.
Fresh wind slabs require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: The new snow and wind slabs are bonding quite well with the old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The weather conditions facilitated a gradual strengthening of the snowpack in particular below approximately 2600 m. The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs formed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all regions only a little snow is lying. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from southwesterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The avalanche danger will increase a little during the day. The wind slabs represent the main danger. Avalanche prone locations are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Mostly the avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be quite stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. Over a wide area up to 15 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In localities where more snow falls the avalanche danger is greater. From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the day progresses, individual moist snow slides are possible. The new snow is lying on the favourable surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind, small wind slabs will form above approximately 1600 m. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In all aspects a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In these regions from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Hardly any snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The snowpack is stable and its surface has a resilient crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow will be deposited on the favourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The danger exists in particular in alpine snow sports terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: New snow is lying on a hard crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The conditions are generally favourable. Fresh wind slabs in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
On Sunday small wind slabs formed in some places. The fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases on steep shady slopes in high Alpine regions. The avalanche prone locations are rare and are easy to recognise.

A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies in the regions with a lot of snow on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.

In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 10 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1000 m. The southwesterly wind has transported the new snow. The old snowpack will be stable over a wide area. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet all the way through and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases, this also applies on steep sunny slopes at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs require caution. A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some snow fell on Sunday. Since Sunday the wind has been moderate to strong. In some localities small wind slabs formed. The more recent wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
Wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. There is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow will be deposited on a crust in all aspects. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Little snow fell on Sunday.
There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects. In some localities small wind slabs formed. The danger of dry avalanches will increase but remain within the current danger level.
The greatest danger remains slipping on hard snow, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steepest sections.
Fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases at their margins. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind, in particular on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface. This applies above approximately 2600 m.
The snowpack is stable and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Tuesday: The avalanche danger will increase from midday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In all aspects in all altitude zones thus far only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are rather rare. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular above approximately 2400 m.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 2400 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. At higher altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
